Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project at Midwestern State University (MSU) entitled Scholarship Opportunities for Academic Recognition (SOAR) will help to meet the demand in Texas for science and technology well-prepared employees. It will focus on strategies designed to increase retention in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) majors such increased peer and faculty supports, programs to facilitate transition to the college environment, and the development of student identity as scientists. These activities have been shown to be particularly effective for underrepresented student populations. Because a high percentage of students at the university are lower-income first-generation and minority students, these strategies will increase retention in those populations and contribute to the diversity of the local workforce. SOAR will serve to strengthen university connections with local high schools during recruitment activities while networking activities with employers improve career preparation and cultivate student interest in the regional STEM industry. SOAR will lead to sustained improvements at the university, in particular the institutionalization of living/learning communities and the science orientation programs.

In addition to providing financial support, SOAR will implement student success strategies to improve retention and graduation for student populations that, despite academic talent and initial motivation, have difficulty persevering in college when confronted with early struggles. The student support model will strengthen science skills early and enable students to develop personal assets that allow them to overcome the challenges of college. This will be accomplished through first-year transition supports, early research experiences in science, a living/learning community, stronger faculty and peer interactions and mentoring, and professional experiences such as internships. These activities will introduce students to scientific thinking, the college environment, and expectations. The university will evaluate the effects of these strategies on retention, graduation, and the success of the scholars post-graduation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Midwestern State University received Award No. 1458185 to create SOAR – Scholarships Opportunities for Academic Recognition. The SOAR program targeted undergraduate students in STEM fields who had academic potential and financial need, which would allow students to focus on academics and reduce the burden of seeking other forms of financial support. SOAR scholars received a variety of support services to help ensure their success, including the Weekend Flight – a program orientation to help transition scholars to college life; an expansive mentoring program; and the opportunity for valuable research and internship experience during the scholars’ final two years in the program.

SOAR recruited two cohorts of students - 11 in Fall 2015 and 9 in Fall 2016, with eligible students replacing scholars who left the program. Of the 20 students entering the program in their first year, 75% were retained for their second year, and 55% graduated in four years, values that were higher than for overall MSU undergraduates. Of the scholars who graduated in four years, 90% were seeking graduate degrees or working in a STEM field six months after graduation. The SOAR program demonstrated a positive impact on student achievement, through financial and extracurricular support of STEM majors.

Survey results on scholar perceptions of the program given in 2017 (considered a baseline) and 2019 show the following trends:

            • “I believe that the scholarship money offered through SOAR has allowed me to focus on my studies, which has enhanced my performance” – “Definitely agree” remained higher than 80%.

            • “I believe that the scholarship money offered through SOAR has eased my financial burden” – “Somewhat” to “Definitely agree” remained at 100%.

            • “I believe that the SOAR mentoring and other academic supports has been beneficial to my academic career.” –  “Definitely agree” increased from 40 to 42%.

            • “I believe that social supports that SOAR offers has encouraged me to remain at Midwestern State University.” –  “Somewhat” to “Definitely agree” remained at 100%.

            • “I believe that the SOAR program has solidified my decision to have a career in STEM after graduation.” –  “Somewhat” to “Definitely agree” remained at 100%.

Intellectual Merit:  Despite academic talent and initial motivation, many STEM majors have difficulty persevering in college when confronted with early struggles. The elements of student support, such as our partnerships with the Academic Success Center, Dean of Students, the Career Management Center, and local entities which provided internship opportunities, were all key to easing these hardships. Frequent events centered on building strong faculty and peer interactions and mentoring, and focused on introducing students to the college environment and to foster scientific thinking. The PI and Co-PIs have a strong history of student mentorship and internship program development, and have all been avid supporters of undergraduate faculty-student research initiatives.

Broader Impacts:  As SOAR was based on strategies to increase retention in STEM majors and encourage the development of student identity as scientists, a model has been created that could be particularly impactful for underrepresented student populations, such as first-generation and minority students. SOAR has served to strengthen our university’s connections with local high schools during recruitment activities, and has additionally build strong relationships with employers. Our program is helping to meet the demand in Texas and Oklahoma for science- and technology-prepared employees.
